content: The PFR blueprint has a minor bug/feature where, in contrast to all other usages I've seen of the "small triangle notation", the triangle just after the word "Proof" points right to indicate "unfolded" and down to indicate "folded". It was the other way around in sphere eversion or LTE IIRC. I talked to @Utensil Song about this and they seem to have got to the bottom of the problem. Is this something worth fixing? I was just looking at the blueprint again when trying to understand what Sebastian has just done changing a 22 to a 12 and I noticed this again.
Ahah! I noticed this in my LeanAPAP blueprint as well.
It's also the other way around in e.g. Lean traces.
I noticed that a long time ago but never took the trouble to fix it. I will try to do it today if it bothers you. This is probably trivial.

Could something confirm that this unfolding triangle are now behaving as expected? Also, I just pushed a blueprint commit which reduces transitive edges in the depgraph by default. So please tell me if anything becomes weird in the PFR graph.

Unfortunately the PFR blueprint is partly broken right now for some reason - none of the recent commits can create a valid build of the blueprint, though the legacy blueprint still works. I have no idea what the issue is here, it started happening even without touching the blueprint source files...

A new texlive-full Docker image was published on January 1st, and it probably updated Python, and pip now errors out if you use it on an externally managed Python installation. There are many solutions, the simplest one being just pinning an older Docker image. I will submit a PR to do that.
Mauricio, where can I find more information about that? I don't even see a failure.
I see. Do you see any issue with the solution at https://stackoverflow.com/a/75722775?
The option you linked to seems fine given the context (setting the PIP_BREAK_SYSTEM_PACKAGES environment variable to 1 would also be fine).
Ok, could you try it in PFR then?

Sure. I've verified just pinning the older Docker image is enough to fix the problem, now I'm verifying export PIP_BREAK_SYSTEM_PACKAGES=1 also fixes it independently. If it does, then I'll submit a PR with both changes, as I think pinning software in CI is a good idea in general.
It works too. I've submitted the PR.
I like the new dark green bubbles for fully verified results!
Ah yes, you picked up this change too. This is part of a series of changes I'm currently implementing.
